| A pirate brother:* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").
* is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore").
* is [herbivorous](/wiki/Herbivore "Herbivore").
* is [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivore "Omnivore").
* is not a valid [polymorphable](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") form.
* is a [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)").
* is normally generated [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful").
* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").
* [likes gold](/wiki/Gold_lover "Gold lover").
* can pick up weapons and food.
* can be seen through [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). |                                                                                     |

The **pirate brother** is a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") added in the [Pirate role patch](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate"). The pirate brother is the [Pirate](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate") [quest guardian](/wiki/Quest_guardian "Quest guardian").

Their main distinction from most other quest guardians (with the exception of the [thugs](/wiki/Thug "Thug") in the [Rogue quest](/wiki/Rogue_quest "Rogue quest")) is that they [like gold](/wiki/Likes_gold "Likes gold"), and are therefore [likely to be generated carrying](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") [some](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid").

In addition to gold, each pirate brother is generated with a cutlass ([scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar")), [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor"), and [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots").

## Encyclopedia entry

The Brethren or Brethren of the Coast were a loose  
coalition of pirates and privateers commonly known as  
buccaneers and active in the seventeenth and eighteenth  
centuries in the Atlantic Ocean, Caribbean Sea and  
Gulf of Mexico.  
  
Based primarily on the island of Tortuga off the coast  
of Haiti and in the city of Port Royal on the island of  
Jamaica, the original Brethren were mostly French  
Huguenot and British Protestants, but their ranks were  
joined by other adventurers of various nationalities  
including Spaniards, and even African sailors, as well  
as escaped slaves and outlaws of various sovereigns.  
  
In keeping with their Protestant and mostly Common  
Law heritage the Brethren were governed by codes of  
conduct that favored legislative decision-making,  
hierarchical command authority, individual rights,  
and equitable division of revenues.

\[ Brethren of the Coast, Wikipedia ]

## References

Reference: [Chris's Pirate Patch](https://github.com/Chris-plus-alphanumericgibberish/NetHack/compare/master...Chris_s_Pirate_Patch.diff)

Pirate brother

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Wikipedia has an article about:
Brethren of the Coast
@ pirate brother
Difficulty 11
Attacks Weapon 1d6 physical, Weapon 1d6 physical
@ pirate brother
Difficulty 11
Attacks

Weapon 1d6 physical, Weapon 1d6 physical

Base level 9
Base experience 196
Speed 12
Base AC 10
Base MR 10
Alignment -3 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 400
Size medium

A pirate brother:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is herbivorous.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is a human.
  • is normally generated peaceful.
  • is strong.
  • likes gold.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can be seen through infravision.

The pirate brother is a monster added in the Pirate role patch. The pirate brother is the Pirate quest guardian.

Their main distinction from most other quest guardians (with the exception of the thugs in the Rogue quest) is that they like gold, and are therefore likely to be generated carrying some.

In addition to gold, each pirate brother is generated with a cutlass (scimitar), leather armor, and high boots.

Encyclopedia entry

The Brethren or Brethren of the Coast were a loose
coalition of pirates and privateers commonly known as
buccaneers and active in the seventeenth and eighteenth
centuries in the Atlantic Ocean, Caribbean Sea and
Gulf of Mexico.

Based primarily on the island of Tortuga off the coast
of Haiti and in the city of Port Royal on the island of
Jamaica, the original Brethren were mostly French
Huguenot and British Protestants, but their ranks were
joined by other adventurers of various nationalities
including Spaniards, and even African sailors, as well
as escaped slaves and outlaws of various sovereigns.

In keeping with their Protestant and mostly Common
Law heritage the Brethren were governed by codes of
conduct that favored legislative decision-making,
hierarchical command authority, individual rights,
and equitable division of revenues.

[ Brethren of the Coast, Wikipedia ]

References

Reference: Chris's Pirate Patch

The '''pirate brother''' is a [[monster]] added in the [[Pirate|Pirate role patch]]. The pirate brother is the [[Pirate]] [[quest guardian]]. 

Their main distinction from most other quest guardians (with the exception of the [[thug]]s in the [[Rogue quest]]) is that they [[likes gold|like gold]], and are therefore [[Monster starting inventory|likely to be generated carrying]] [[zorkmid|some]].

In addition to gold, each pirate brother is generated with a cutlass ([[scimitar]]), [[leather armor]], and [[high boots]].

==Encyclopedia entry==

{{encyclopedia|
The Brethren or Brethren of the Coast were a loose 
coalition of pirates and privateers commonly known as 
buccaneers and active in the seventeenth and eighteenth
centuries in the Atlantic Ocean, Caribbean Sea and 
Gulf of Mexico.

Based primarily on the island of Tortuga off the coast 
of Haiti and in the city of Port Royal on the island of 
Jamaica, the original Brethren were mostly French 
Huguenot and British Protestants, but their ranks were 
joined by other adventurers of various nationalities 
including Spaniards, and even African sailors, as well 
as escaped slaves and outlaws of various sovereigns.

In keeping with their Protestant and mostly Common 
Law heritage the Brethren were governed by codes of 
conduct that favored legislative decision-making, 
hierarchical command authority, individual rights, 
and equitable division of revenues.
|[ Brethren of the Coast, Wikipedia ]
}}
